author: Washedup11
body:
I don’t know if you’re being a troll or what.

I’ll entertain you I guess

The S&P 500 is an index of 500 stocks in the US. Generally speaking they are 500 of the largest companies in the country. Walmart, Target, Apple, Visa, Disney, Pepsi, Tesla, Microsoft, Boeing, JP Morgan, American Airlines, Lowe’s, Home Depot, etc - large companies that are household names.

It’s diverse in terms of sector and is able to fairly accurately reflect the state of the whole stock market due to its size and diversity.

So, historically, the return on the S&P (the countries largest and 500 “best” companies) is around 10% a year. The highest return it’s had has been 38.46% and it’s lowest has been a -37.22%.

author: 7thAccountDontDelete
body:
Yes if you account yield on cost and not yield on current price. Apple has a .67% yield, or $0.82/sh, right now but someone who has owned Apple since 2010 when it was split-adjusted $10/sh would be getting a 8.2% yield. You can apply this to lots of stocks as well. If you bought all of these in 2010, 

V- $1.28 div, .61% current yield, 7.27% yield on cost

HD- $6 div, 2.17% current yield, 18.9% yield on cost

JNJ- $4.04 div, 2.74% current yield, 6.5% yield on cost

UNH- $5 div, 1.47% current yield, 14.2% yield on cost

author: bilbao111
body:
Irish Central Bank Governor:

>The Central Bank cautioned that a key risk to global financial conditions was what it described as a “growing disconnect between certain financial market valuations and the real economy”, most notably in the US where consumer confidence metrics and equity market valuations have diverged.

>It said markets were pricing in a “V-shaped” rebound in activity, supported by better-than-expected macroeconomic data.

>As a result market volatility measures have dropped sharply in recent months but it warned these measures do not appear to fully capture the heightened levels of economic policy uncertainty”.

author: thrwy8234
body:
damn. check out the historical revenues for DKS:

https://www.macrotrends.net/stocks/charts/DKS/dicks-sporting-goods/revenue

incredible, considering retail apocalypse and all. makes sense though, since you have to physically try out any equipment you want to buy

i think the key to surviving in retail will be to provide value to customers in a unique way that draws them to the stores, while combining that with a strong online presence

there's also this from the [retail apocalypse](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Retail_apocalypse) wiki:

"IHL found that for each retailer that is closing stores in 2019 more than five retail chains are opening stores, which is up from the 3.7 ratio in 2018. IHL also reported that the number of chains adding stores in 2019 has increased 56%, while the number of closing stores has decreased by 66% in the last year."

it should be noted that GME is closing between 400 and 450 stores though:

https://www.cnn.com/2020/09/10/investing/gamestop-store-closures/index.html

i've also looked at several stores that are within the "specialty retail" group:

https://finviz.com/screener.ashx?v=121&f=ind_specialtyretail&o=pc

sorted by price-to-cash (P/C). a lot of them had great earnings in the last quarter, and many went up after. GME is the cheapest in the group in terms of P/C ratio, perhaps indicating a degree of upside

further, MIK and BBW have earnings on dec. 3rd

maybe, *maybe*, completely guessing: their earnings might provide an indication of what will happen with GME on dec. 8, ah

although, that should be combined with the fact that it's a console-release year, along with the fact that gaming is a massive and growing industry

Thank you for your time and perspective!

author: EquivalentSelection
body:
You can't get rich overnight with those underlyings. Those are get-rich-slowly companies. They belong in your retirement account and you check on them a few times per year.

If your source of income comes from working, you should be dedicating a portion of your paycheck to your retirement account - and a portion to your YOLO account.

As money shows up in your YOLO account, you light that fuse and pray for it to be a bottle rocket. If it explodes in your face, you wait until next payday. If it's a bottle rocket - you send 75% of those profits off to pasture (i.e. lock it up in a retirement account). The other 25% is a bonus bet you get to make, instead of having to wait for another paycheck.

You want to be playing with underlyings that are just stupid, volatile and wild. Super high IV when it's not earnings time. The ones that just make no sense, and they're swinging up and down violently every day. The more drama, the better. If you were betting on a horse, you don't want the big stud horse that everyone is betting on because the payout sucks. You want the horse that stopped in the middle of the last race to eat the shit on the ground from the horses in front of it. The one that has tourette syndrome. You want... the [Becky](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MFs9jLN4siQ&ab_channel=dnasewell) version of a horse. You will have no damn clue where it's going, but it's going somewhere - and fast. It's the unexpected move.

When you buy that cheap OTM, and Becky happens to pop off while she's carrying you in Geralds bucket - you're turning that $100 into $10k. Risk $100 to make $10k? Fuck yes, all day long. Except, you can't do it with just any stock. It needs to be a Becky stock. (Can someone make me a meme of this, please?) How do you find Becky stocks? Wait for someone to post one here, and you wait for everyone to start saying "[mine](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=p-3e0EkvIEM&ab_channel=as0k)". When that happens, it's go time.

author: Meymo
body:
This was a fantastic read and mirrors some of my own thoughts regarding the market. I found it interesting that they're also stating that we will have a *"likelihood of low policy rates for the rest of our lives".* Which is the same thing that many commentators on this sub-reddit have also been saying.

For fun, [here's the historical performance](https://www.portfoliovisualizer.com/backtest-portfolio?s=y&timePeriod=4&startYear=1985&firstMonth=1&endYear=2020&lastMonth=12&calendarAligned=true&includeYTD=false&initialAmount=10000&annualOperation=0&annualAdjustment=0&inflationAdjusted=true&annualPercentage=0.0&frequency=2&rebalanceType=1&absoluteDeviation=5.0&relativeDeviation=25.0&showYield=false&reinvestDividends=true&benchmark=VFINX&portfolioNames=false&portfolioName1=Portfolio+1&portfolioName2=Portfolio+2&portfolioName3=Portfolio+3&symbol1=TDG&allocation1_1=5&symbol2=ADBE&allocation2_1=5&symbol3=ADSK&allocation3_1=5&symbol4=ANSS&allocation4_1=5&symbol5=INTU&allocation5_1=5&symbol6=PAYC&allocation6_1=5&symbol7=VRTX&allocation7_1=5&symbol8=ANET&allocation8_1=5&symbol9=MA&allocation9_1=5&symbol10=PYPL&allocation10_1=5&symbol11=V&allocation11_1=5&symbol12=ABMD&allocation12_1=5&symbol13=ISRG&allocation13_1=5&symbol14=ALGN&allocation14_1=5&symbol15=TTWO&allocation15_1=5&symbol16=ETSY&allocation16_1=5&symbol17=XLNX&allocation17_1=5&symbol18=MNST&allocation18_1=5&symbol19=FTNT&allocation19_1=5&symbol20=NOW&allocation20_1=5) of the "high growth" picks that JPM outlines on page 9 (equally weighted, thereby not optimized towards any specific metric), so we can revisit this in 2022 and see how they did. As a data point, historically, it looks like the running CAGR of this blend is around 40.64%. If someone wants to buy this allocation, they can do so quite simply via fractional shares.

author: bibibabibu
body:
Honestly, Paysafe isn't better strictly from a financial perspective. I posted this below as a quick comparison, I will copy-paste again:

Paysafe forecasts their topline at a 13%. PYPL has 19% forecasted growth (PYPL is known for conservative estimates as well, it's frequently blown this up)

Bottom line (EBITDA) growth: 17% vs PYPL's 20%

Payment (transactions) volume growth: 15% vs Paypal's **30-40%.**

EBITDA margin: 33% vs PYPL's 29%. I wouldn't call a 4% difference as being "much better"...

The only plus of BFT is that it's Bill Foley-related, and it's got a unique niche going for a targeted segment of the i-gaming/e-gambling segment. By actual financials, it's completely average.

Source: Page 47 of the BFT investor presentation [https://s25.q4cdn.com/579018173/files/doc\_presentations/2020/Foley-Trasimene-Acquisition-Corp.-II-and-Paysafe-investor-presentation.pdf](https://s25.q4cdn.com/579018173/files/doc_presentations/2020/Foley-Trasimene-Acquisition-Corp.-II-and-Paysafe-investor-presentation.pdf)

The only plus of BFT is that it's Bill Foley-related, and it's got a unique niche going for a targeted segment of the i-gaming/e-gambling segment. By actual financials, it's completely average. 

Source: Page 47 of the BFT investor presentation [https://s25.q4cdn.com/579018173/files/doc\_presentations/2020/Foley-Trasimene-Acquisition-Corp.-II-and-Paysafe-investor-presentation.pdf](https://s25.q4cdn.com/579018173/files/doc_presentations/2020/Foley-Trasimene-Acquisition-Corp.-II-and-Paysafe-investor-presentation.pdf)

author: mvbraml
body:
I agree ETH will catch a bid.  It has more regulatory clarity because it was listed by Paypal and CME.  They are more conservative about listings than the crypto native exchanges.

Institutions and UHNWI are driving this bubble.  They're not going to use their BTC profits to 100x pump shitcoins on Bittrex, Poloniex, and Binance like the retail traders did in the last bubble.

The biggest shitcoin narratives "low fees, high TPS" have been rekt since then too.  Traders who traded out of their BTC and ETH positions for shitcoins in the last bubble got burned badly.  I don't think people will fall for it to the same extent as they did last time.

The market clearly values the network effects and liquidity of BTC and ETH over the high throughput, low fees, and "better tech" shitcoin narratives.

author: cman_14
body: PYPL/SQ

Bitcoin supply and demand factors:

Bitcoin’s supply is famously limited, with only 900 per day being created currently. Compare this to a trade volume around 3,000,000 daily. Unlike most commodities, an increased price does not lead to increased supply, so your Econ 101 supply curve is flat.

The recent bull run has instead been driven by increased demand, with four primary factors:

* Institutional demand is the biggest story. When 150+ year old insurance company MassMutual buys in with a cool $250m, you know institutional acceptance is finally happening. Institutions hold just 15% of all Bitcoin and we should expect to see that increase dramatically this year.
* New retail exposure. New demographics of retail buyers now have crypto exposure through easy, established channels like PayPal and Cashapp.
* Payments use case. PornHub going crypto-only is a big deal IMO. Many people globally don’t have credit cards and cryptocurrency holds the promise of actually increasing the reach of ecommerce. The internet revolutionized content delivery but has always been missing the same level of revolution in payments to complete the cycle. Porn has always been an innovation leader on the Internet, and if the PornHub experiment is successful, it could open the door for others.
* Gold replacement. Investment banks have issued statements saying their clients are shifting their gold allocation to Bitcoin. Also, a survey of Millenials found that they prefer Bitcoin to gold. As fiat currencies devalue globally, Bitcoin gains.

We are just getting started and this bull run has a long way to go. I’ve been in crypto professionally since 2013 and IMO we are nowhere close to the next top.

author: thomasjadallah
body:
Currently I am in a few stocks and ETFs, mostly tech. I set up an account through Schwab for that which is annoying because I can’t make an online account with them until I’m an adult, but I usually write down what I want my dad to order for me and give him the money and he’ll buy it for me. 

Stocks-wise, I have some AAPL, AMZN, and TSLA. 

I am considering buying into the financial sector as I think it will do quite well in the coming years as we recover from COVID, so for that I’m looking at V, MA, PYPL, and JPM, as well as another tech stock, TSM(company that makes chips for Apple and I believe Apple will be doing a lot more work with them in the future so there’s growth potential especially as Apple begins to move away from Intel). 

As for ETFs, I am in VTI and SKYY, and I may have some FTEC but don’t remember off the top of my head. I am looking into buying some ICLN as I believe it has potential to do well under the upcoming Biden administration. 

So I guess my portfolio isn’t exactly what you’d call diverse, but I’m gonna start buying into some other sectors than tech, although I guess I have fairly high risk tolerance anyways.

body:
It’s a solid company with an even more solid team. PayPal mafia has an impeccable track record of startups. 

Right now, Palantir’s contracts seem small but that’s how they work- an entity will test out the software on a small contract and as they become dependent on it, larger adoption and higher profits follow. 

The stock definitely got blown up a bit so the correction is expected. For the long haul, I think there is huge upside.

author: Cameron_Impastato
body:
Square. 

Square sells customers actual Bitcoin, PayPal sells its paper value. Square is implementing behavioral economics through its card, PayPal is banking on Venmo’s social network. Square is the easy and cheap medium businesses chose to use for physical transactions. PayPal is the established and expensive medium businesses have to use for online transactions.

One is building for the future, the other is cashing in on the present. The world economy is moving to crypto. Better bet on the one that’s getting ahead of it.

author: tiger_prime
body:
Paysafe is the stodgy european Paypal that's been around forever (1996). 10% revenue growth is very underwhelming for an e-payments company. 

$9B is already richly valued (Blackstone paid $3.9B for it in 2017, then a 60% premium to its trading price). Congrats to Blackstone making 130% on their 3-year flip of it at NAV. Suggesting it's worth 2-3x *more* is ridiculous.
